marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Isaac E. Holmes was a United States Representative from South Carolina, 1839-1851.

Collection contains legal papers, ca. 1787, of John Bee Holmes, father of Isaac E. Holmes, concerning a case involving John Young; and correspondence of Isaac E. Holmes while in congress, consisting chiefly of requests and recommendations for political appointments.
John Holland was a resident of Chatham County, Georgia.
Papers and an account book concerning a debt owed to John Holland by Zachariah Cox, a Philadelphia merchant.
David Holmes was governor of the Mississippi Territory and later of the state of Mississippi.
Correspondence concerning the early settlement of the Mississippi Territory, the territorial militia, and Holmes' election as governor in 1826 and subsequent resignation.
Edward Hooker was a college president in Cambridge, South Carolina; of Farmington (Hartford County), Connecticut.

Family letters of Hooker describing the slave trade in South Carolina, several trips made to that state, his life in Cambridge (South Carolina), his position at South Carolina College, Columbia (now the University of South Carolina), trouble with the British, and the British frigate Leopard; and letters of John Hooker, Edward's brother, a lawyer in Columbia, S.C., describing an earthquake, 1812, his first dose of castor oil, a trip to Catawba Springs, North Carolina, the attitude of the inhabitants of Columbia toward the War of 1812, and religious fervor in the town.
John Hollingsworth was a plantation owner of Edgefield District, South Carolina.
Bills of sale for slaves sold by John Hollingsworth and a contract between D.F. Hollingsworth and his overseer. Included also are papers concerning the settlement of Hollingworth's estate.
Abiel Holmes was a minister in the Congregational Church of Cambridge, Middlesex County, Massachusetts
Letter of Abiel Holmes acknowledging a gift from his former parishoners to the American Education Society.
Gabriel Holmes was governor of North Carolina, 1821-1824.
A form letter from Gabriel Holmes, governor of North Carolina, to Allen Trimble, acting governor of Ohio.
Daniel Hoit was a Sandwich, New Hampshire, resident.

Collection consists of Hoit's political papers and abolitionists' letters to him. The contents concern the tariff, Jackson campaign, anti-slavery sentiments and strategy, and the Liberty Party. One document appears to be a draft or copy of a memorandum from a Liberty Party, Home Squadron, candidate accepting the nomination. The candidate sets forth his answers to questions about the monetary affairs of the country, the act of Congress for the distribution of the proceeds of public lands, the establishment of the Home Squadron, and the tariff. Correspondents include a number of congressmen, especially N.H. politicians. Some of these are David Barker, Jr., John Parker Hale, Amos Tuck, and Nathaniel Rogers. One letter contains a vivid description of a physical scuffle between two House members, Bell and Turney.
Unprocessed collection. Cataloged from accession record.
Hines Holt was a lawyer, member of the United States Congress, and Confederate congressman, from Georgia.
Papers of Hines Holt, containing one certificate and a letter of advice to his son.
Silas Holmes was a physician and naval officer.

Letter written on April 9, 1838, by Jeremiah B. Day, President of Yale, to Holmes. Day noted that he was enclosing a certificate, which was a general recommendation of the character of Holmes. The recommendation is also endorsed by Benjamin Silliman, professor of chemistry and natural history at Yale.
Lydia E. Hollingsworth was a Catholic student at St. Joseph's College in Emmitsburg, Maryland.

Letters to Hollingsworth from family members in Hagerstown, Maryland. The letters concern news of family and friends in Maryland, parental advice to their student daughter, and a description of her sister's work in school.
Ethel Holtzclaw was a resident of Greenville County, South Carolina.
Deeds to lands in Greenvile County, South Carolina.
John C. Hood was assistant quartermaster of Meadow Township, Johnston County, North Carolina.

Papers of Hood while he was in charge of official aid to families of Confederate soldiers, with names of committee members, money paid out for relief, names of soldiers' families and corn and meat supplies held by each. Also, Civil War letters from B.R. Hood, serving in the Camp Guards and in the 24th North Carolina Regiment, and from David W. Hood, in the 67th North Carolina Regiment, describing camp life and food, the second battle of Manassas (Bull Run) and other engagements and skirmishes, and the possibility of hiring a substitute.
Aurelia Hooper was a resident of Caswell County, North Carolina.

Primarily Civil War letters from Private George Leitz, 17th Virginia Regiment, C.S.A., to Miss Hooper, including a description of the Confederate gunboat Neuse under construction near Kinston, North Carolina. A letter, 1871, refers to property lost in the Chicago Fire. Also included is a pledge signed by those interested in forming a volunteer rifle company.
Matthew Holmes was a resident of Londonderry, Pennsylvania.
Receipts for money paid by the town of Londenderry to Matthew and John A. Holmes.
John W. Holberton was a resident of Canandaigua, New York.

Letters to John W. Holberton, for the most part concerned with business and personal matters including letters reporting the failure of brokerage and banking firms in New York, 1857; letters on Democratic Party politics, 1857; and a letter from William H. Powell, an artist, advocating that the United States government employ American artists rather than foreigners such as Horace Vernet.
Julian J. Hollingsworth was part of a Missouri family.

The majority of the letters are written by Sarah Walker of Gentryville, Mo., to her daughter, Mrs. Julian J. Hollingsworth, concerning family matters centering around her sons, William Nelson Walker and George W. Walker, both of the 25th Missouri Volunteers. Seven of the letters are written from the battlefield and give details of battles and army life; four are from William Nelson and George W. Walker; one is from Joseph Hollingsworth of the 7th Indiana volunteers, 1862, August 18; and one is from Julian to his wife, 1862, July 24. There is also a letter (1857, June 15) written by John M. Smith, Eldora, Hardin Co., Iowa, to his cousin in Texas regarding his thoughts on abolition and one from George Walker, Sr., (1867, April 2) to his son-in-law, Julian.
Unprocessed collection. Cataloged from accession records.
John W. Holland was a resident of Lexington (Davidson County), North Carolina.

Correspondence among members of a family in North Carolina, Virginia, the Midwest and the Southwest. The letters describe the trip west; prices in western states; and the political and racial situation in Abbeville County, S.C., 1876.
Seth Hollister was a resident of Washington (Litchfield County), Connecticut.

Letters to Hollister from his cousins in the 8th Connecticut Regiment during the Civil War and from other soldiers describing the training center at Annapolis, Md.; camp life in Virginia and North Carolina; and New Bern, North Carolina.
Robert W. Honnoll was a Confederate Army officer of the 23rd Regiment, Tennessee Volunteers, stationed at Corinth, Mississippi.
Letters of Lieutenant Honnoll concerning camp life and family matters, and commenting on prospects for peace and opposition to Lincoln in the North.
John Bell Hood was a Confederate Army officer, stationed at Nashville (Davidson County), Tennessee.

Miscellaneous papers of Lieut. General Hood, including a letter, 1864, from Hood to General Joseph Wheeler asking his cooperation in a charge about to be made; a report to Secretary of War James A. Seddon concerning an engagement at Franklin, Tennessee; an order pertaining to furloughs; a letter to Hood containing an order for Cheatham's Corps; a pass; and biographical information.
L. C. Hook was a resident of Hook's Mills, Hampshire County, West Virginia.

Personal and business letters to L. C. Hook, including a letter from Charles W. Swisher, secretary of state of West Virginia and Republican gubernatorial candidate, enclosing a political broadside by Governor W. M. O. Dawson in his behalf.
Hamilton B. Holt was editor of the Independent, in New York, New York.
Letter to Hamilton B. Holt from John Sharp Williams concerning the operations of the stock market and financial institutions in New York.
